item.title: About Me
item.description: My name is Eric Joraskie and I am a computer science graduate student at Northeastern University. I’ve had an unusual path into CS. Prior to a string of injuries resulting in my football career prematurely coming to an end, I thought I’d end up playing in the NFL. Upon medically retiring from football toward the end of my sophomore year at Northwestern University, I began to focus my studies on neuroscience, which I found to be exciting enough to keep my attention.

item.title: Athletics
item.description: Having played football for 16 years and having been a full scholarship athlete at Northwestern, I’m often met with surprise when people find out I don’t watch or follow any sports. So, although I can definitely talk about sports generally, if you were to ask me something specific about a player or team, it is likely I will not have the answer. However, I do enjoy being an athlete. For fun, here is my high school highlight tape:

item.title: Finding The Right Path
item.description: I graduated from Northwestern with a degree in neuroscience. The reason I studied neuro was questionable by educational investment standards: I thought it was really cool. After I medically retired from football, I wasn’t really sure what to do with myself. The college athlete experience is a different conversation entirely, so I’ll save it for another post, but having grown up in small central Pennsylvania town where football was pretty much the only thing people had or cared about, I hadn’t spent tons of time considering life after football.

item.title: Photography
item.description: I’ve been fascinated with photography since I was a kid.* Luckily for me, my high school had a TV Studio extracurricular that gave me the opportunity to spend a lot of time using DSLRs, shoulder-mount video cameras and a few different professional photo and video editing softwares, so I was able to get a reasonable amount of practice fairly early on. Now I mainly use a DJI Mavic Air 2, a Sony Cybershot that is a few years old but still great, and I have a Rylo (r.

item.title: Projects
item.description: I’ve written a lot of code and enjoy writing code, so that volume is growing. That being said, I’m relatively selective about what I keep in a public repository. Here are a couple of projects that I’ve worked on with links to what is available. I will update this page as I make more code available on GitHub. Othello Optical Escape

item.title: Reading List
item.description: I read a lot. It’s usually nonfiction but I’ve included some of my favorite novels too. Here is a quick list of eight of my favorites I’d be willing to risk my recommendation reputation on. I’ve linked them all to their page on Goodreads and the authors are linked to the best info source I could quickly find. I’m actually not really a fan of Goodreads (mainly their web page design; I think their pages are very cluttered), but I figured it was better than linking directly to Amazon, although I understand it’s only really one additional step.
